OVERVIEW OF BGMU SAFETY PROGRAM



PERSONNEL

Bowling Green Municipal Utilities employees a full time Safety Director, Safety Coordinator and two part-time Safety Officers at the Treatment Plants.

The Safety Director and Safety Coordinator is responsible for the overall development, administration and supervision of activities required by OSHA, EPA, DOT and other federal and state agencies, to safeguard all BGMU employees. The Safety Officers at the Treatment Plants have a primary job consisting in Plant Operations and then secondary as Safety, in which they coordinate all inspections, safety equipment and employee assistance in Safety at the Treatment Plants.



PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION

Bowling Green Municipal Utilities on April 27, 1989 hired a full-time Safety Director so that BGMU could develop and implement a written Safety Program. With that hiring, the major obstacle was achieving compliance in the OSHA, EPA and DOT regulations so that BGMU and all the employees would have a safe and healthful work environment. On March 3, 2008 Bowling Green Municipal Utilities hired a Safety Coordinator to assist the Safety Director with all health and safety issues within the company. To this date the Safety Department now handles all of the compliance programs in the Electric, Water/Wastewater and General Services Divisions, with the only exception being environmental issues that directly involve the Industrial Wastewater Pretreatment Program, which the Industrial Pretreatment Director handles. Bowling Green Municipal Utilities initialized a Accident/Safety Committee on October 26, 1994 starting with a member from each work area for a total of 10 members. This committee reviews accidents/incidents and makes recommendations to submit for the BGMU Managers for their interpretation and implementation.  Bowling Green Municipal Utilities insures that each employee upon being hired has access to the employee handbook through our internal intranet system, in which this book expla

ins many benefits, employment rules, insurance plans, work hours and policies.



TRAINING

Bowling Green Municipal Utilities Safety Department develops and conducts monthly safety meetings, which are coordinated with department supervisors, so that employees can attend. The safety meetings that are conducted with the employees range from Hazard Communication, Pole Top/Bucket Rescue, First Aid/CPR to Confined Space training to name a few. A complete list of monthly training is sent to each System Manager three months prior to the beginning of the New Year. The training for each employee is recorded and filed.

Bowling Green Municipal Utilities also conducts training sessions with other agencies which include the local Fire Departments, Local Emergency Planning Committees, Emergency Medical Services, local Universities and other Utilities. The training with these agencies proves that BGMU has a good community service orientated background for safety training. These sessions include but are not limited to Electrical Safety, Hazardous Materials, Confined Spaces, Inspections, etc.



EQUIPMENT

Bowling Green Municipal Utilities has established a policy to ensure that the employees and their workplace are in a safe and healthful work environment. BGMU is committed to each employee by providing the employee with certain safety equipment, with a brief list of: safety glasses, hard hats, rain gear, hearing protection, respiratory protection, fall arresting equipment, etc. The Safety Department is constantly reviewing each job function (Hazard Assessments), to ensure that all aspects of health and safety are being provided to BGMU employees.



REPORTING INJURIES

Bowling Green Municipal Utilities is committed to employee health and safety, but due to working conditions that sometimes cannot be controlled, accidents occur. If you should suffer any work-related injury, no matter how minor, it shall be reported to your supervisor immediately. This First Report of Injury should

also be reported to the Human Resources Director or Coordinator so the appropriate accident reports can be filled out.

Each employee will also be responsible to fill out Safety Report and Investigation Report to submit to their immediate Supervisor and then it will be submitted to the Department Head.  After they have finished it the report is submitted to the General Manager and then it is routed to the Safety/Accident Committee for their review and recommendation back to BGMU Managers.

GENERAL OVERVIEW

WATER/WASTEWATER DIVISION



Bowling Green Municipal Utilities (BGMU) is a combined municipal utility with water, wastewater, electric and fiber services.  The accompanying organizational chart illustrates the general structure of BGMU's Water/Wastewater Division.  This Emergency Response Plan is prepared by the Water/Wastewater Division for use in the event of a crisis.



BGMU's Water Treatment Plant serves the potable water supply needs of the city of Bowling Green, KY (KY Permit-PWSID-1140038) and a large portion of Warren County, KY.  BGMU has over 23,315 water service connections (19,928 residential and 3,387 commercial) serving approximately 61,000 people within the city limits of Bowling Green and an addition estimated 80,000 people via master meters.



The Water Treatment Plant is located north of downtown Bowling Green, KY at 16 Chestnut Street.  BGMU uses the Big Barren River as their raw water source.  BGMU's Water Treatment Plant provides flocculation, sedimentation, disinfection, filtration and fluoridation processes with a capacity of 30mgd.  The finished product is pumped from the clearwell's to the distribution system.  The average flow per year is 18 million gallons per day.



The distribution system consists of 103 miles or 546,603 feet of distribution water mains, 187 miles or 987,213 feet of transmission water mains, over 2300 fire hydrants, over 5,800 water valves, four (4) pumping stations and five (5) above ground level storage tanks.

The storage tanks have a total capacity of eleven (11) million gallons of water.  The distribution system is designed to provide adequate flow for domestic, industrial and firefighting needs.  The average household uses an estimated 250 gallons a day.



BGMU's Wastewater Treatment Plant serves the sanitary and industrial wastewater treatment needs of the city of Bowling Green, KY (KY Permit - 0022403) and portions of Warren County, KY.  BGMU has approximately 18,000 wastewater service connections serving approximately 61,000 people within the city limits.  Outside the city limits, various industries and other services in portions of Warren County account for another estimated 38,000 people.



The Wastewater Treatment Plant is located northwest of downtown Bowling Green, KY at 1189 Preston Street, adjacent to Hobson Grove Park and Golf Course.  BGMU's Wastewater Treatment Plant utilizes an sequencing batch reactor system.  Discharge goes into the Big Barren River, flowing approximately 800 feet to the rear of the facility.  The average daily flow through the facility is 8 million gallons per day.



The wastewater collection system consists of approximately 267 miles of gravity wastewater, 23 miles of force mains, 65 wastewater lift stations and thousands of wastewater manholes.



The Water/Wastewater Division has 73 employees with varied and numerous skills.  Many of the supervisors and all stand-by employees have radio-equipped vehicles and/or a portable radio with them at all times.  On a rotating basis, crews, and supervisors are "subject to call" for services needed after hours.  In the event of a major emergency involving loss of telephone or radio communications, designated employees have been instructed to report to their normal work area for assignment to the emergency response activities.



While the following Emergency Response Plan is designated to provide detailed resource information to those responding to emergency conditions, it does not give exte

nsive details on exact responses to specific events.  Individual events have infinite variability and plans that are too specific may be useless in response to the event.  The Emergency Response Plan serves as a list of available resources/information and contains general instructions related to select types of emergency events.  More detailed information and instruction for responding to an emergency condition will be provided by Supervision and those directly in charge.

Bowling Green Municipal Utilities (BGMU) is a combined municipal utility with electric, water, sewer and fiber services.  The accompanying organizational chart illustrates the general structure of BGMU's Electric Division located in downtown Bowling Green, KY at 801 Center Street.  This Emergency Response Plan is specifically written for use by the Electric Division in the event of a crisis.



BGMU's Electric Division serves the electrical needs of the city of Bowling Green, KY and a portion of Warren County, KY thru the Kentucky Revised Statutes and the Little TVA Act.  BGMU has approximately 29,000 service connections serving approximately 61,000 people.  This includes approximately 24,400 residential meters and 4,600 commercial institutions.  BGMU is a Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) Distributor, receiving wholesale power from TVA at 161 KV at three delivery point substations.



The distribution system consists of over 267 miles of overhead electrical lines, 78 miles of underground lines.  BGMU also has 13 substations of which three also serve as delivery points and two are dedicated to WKU:

The Electric Division has 109 employees with varied and numerous skills.  Many of the supervisors and all stand-by employees have a radio-equipped vehicle and/or a portable radio with them at all times.  On a rotation basis, crews, and the supervisors are "subject to call" for services needed after hours.  In the event of a major emergency involving loss of telephone or radio communications, designated employees have been instructed to report to their normal work areas for assignment to the emergency response activities.

More detailed information and instruction for responding to an emergency condition will be provided by Supervision and those directly in charge.

***ENVIRONMENTAL ACTIVITIES***



Treatment facility Operator(s) on duty shall monitor and determine the severity of any leak or spill that could result in a hazardous/emergency incident.  All leaks or spills shall be reported to the Chief Operator and Safety Department immediately.  The facilities are occupied and monitored 24 hours a day and 7 days a week.



***SAFETY/SECURITY***



It shall be the responsibility of the BGMU to ensure safety at the site of any emergency.  BGMU shall have the responsibility to ensure total site security.  BGMU Employees, who will not be specifically assigned for HAZMAT, may be utilized as needed for security purposes after non-contaminated areas have been established.  Each facility is fully enclosed with fencing and secured with electric gates that require identification of the entrant.

BOWLING GREEN MUNICIPAL UTILITIES

HAZARD COMMUNICATION PROGRAM



GENERAL



The following written hazard communication program has been established for the Bowling Green Municipal Utilities, Electric, Water/Wastewater and General Services Division.  It is the intention of the program to provide each employee with information pertaining to potential hazards on the job site and a means of reducing and/or elimination such potential hazards, when possible.



(Section 1A) Container Labeling



The supervisor on each site will verify that all containers received for use, by personnel under his/her direction, will:



?    Be clearly labeled as to the contents,

?    Note the appropriate hazard warnings,

?    List the name and address of the manufacturer,

?    Verify SDS arrives with or before containers



No containers will be released for use until the above data is verified.



(Section 1B) Safety Data Sheets



Safety Data Sheets are available on-line through the BGMU website as well as available on all BGMU computers.  Hard copies of the SDS's are available at the Safety Department's Office if requested.



Indexes of SDS's for all chemicals to which departmental employees may be exposed will be kept in a designated area within the appropriate departments marked "RIGHT TO KNOW" COMPLIANCE CENTER.



It will be the responsibility of each department's purchasing agents to ensure SDS's are supplied at the time of purchase for any chemical.  Before chemicals are released out to the employee the SDS should be on site.



SDS's will be available for review to all employees during each work shift by the on-line system.  Copies will be made available

upon request to the Department Supervisors or Safety Department.



(Section 1C) Employee Training and Information



It will be the responsibility of each Department Supervisor to ensure that each new employee will attend a safety training session and be given training on Hazardous Materials Handling before starting work.  The training will consist of:



?    Chemicals and their hazards in their work areas;

?    How to lessen or prevent exposure to these hazardous chemicals;

?    What BGMU has done to lessen or prevent worker's exposure to these chemicals;

?    Procedures to follow if they are exposed to these chemicals.



Before any new hazardous chemical is introduced into any department in BGMU, each employee will be given information in the same manner as the safety training.  The Department Supervisor will be responsible for seeing that SDS's on the new chemical are available.  All SDS's that arrive in each department that is new to the company, the original should be sent to the Safety Department as soon as possible.





Safety Meetings are held throughout the year and Hazardous Materials used by personnel will be discussed if employees have any questions.  Notices will be posted on the employee bulletin boards that provide an explanation of our container labeling system and the locations of the written Hazard Communication Program in the various work sites within BGMU.  Also the Safety Officer within each department will also provide the necessary information if the employee needs information between Safety Meetings.



LIST OF HAZARDOUS CHEMICALS



A complete list of Hazardous chemicals used in each division is accessible to the employee in the "RIGHT TO KNOW" COMPLIANCE CENTERS.



HAZARDOUS NONROUTINE TASKS (HNT's)



At various times employees will be required to perform Hazardous non-routine tasks.  HNT's are defined as those tasks, involving hazards, which are performed on an unscheduled or random basis.  Listed are several types of HNT's normally performed

e in the specific areas, and copies are available;

?    Procedures to follow if they are exposed.



All Department Supervisors will coordinate the supplying of this information to said contractors and their respective employees, prior to their entering the work site.



This Hazard Communication Program was established in accordance with the requirements of CFR 1910.200 (e).

CHLORINE



  Chlorine is used, on a regular basis, at Bowling Green Municipal Utilities' Water Treatment Plants.  The Commonwealth of Kentucky mandates the use of a disinfectant Chlorine in Public Water Supplies.  Chlorine is used as a primary and secondary disinfectant at the Water Treatment Plant.  The average amount of Chlorine used is 550 pounds per day.



  The Water Treatment Plant feed system consists of seven (7) W & T V-Notch type chlorinators.  During normal operation at the Water Treatment Plant, ten (10) cylinders (1 ton each) are connected in parallel to the manifold system.  The manifolds are a split type with automatic switchover systems allowing selected amounts of cylinders to be used at a given time.



  Storage room maximum capacity at the Water Treatment Plant is fifteen (one) 1 ton cylinders.  Normal operation at the Water Treatment Plant would be five (5) cylinders in service with five (5) cylinders ready to switch over for use.  The other five (5) cylinders are stored on cradles at floor level.



  Within this section are schematics of the chlorine feed and storage areas for the Water Treatment facility.  Additionally, equipment information, "Kit B" emergency repair kit location, and SDS data and chlorine information are included.





































BGMU CHLORINE INFORMATON AND RESPONSE PROCEDURES



General Operations and Maintenance



I.    Plant Operators with assistance from other Operators or Maintenance Technicians shall unload and/or load, switch over

and transfer cylinders within the cradles with a minimum of 2 personnel using the buddy system with proper radio and/or hand signal communications at all times.



II.    While any work is being performed inside the Chlorine Room a hand-held Chlorine Monitor shall be turned on and carried while work is being performed which will provide personal safety in conjunction with the stationary units.



III.    Communications shall be maintained at all times during the general operations and maintenance of cylinders.  A Safety person shall be standing by outside the room and shall have a radio and monitor all actions being performed in the room.



IV.    The 2nd and 3rd Shift Operators shall never enter the Chlorine Room upon a confirmation of a leak.  These personnel shall notify the Dispatcher and they shall immediately notify the emergency contacts which include the on-call Maintenance Technician, on-call Supervisor and on-call Safety Department personnel.  This can include the Hazardous Materials Team if deemed necessary.



V.    When the 2nd and 3rd Shift Operators are working alone during their shift they shall notify the Dispatcher that the Chlorine alarm has activated and they shall evacuate to the initial staging area.  Personnel called in will also respond will go to the initial staging area to meet the Operator.



VI.    Self-Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA) shall be worn during all maintenance and leak responses along with appropriate personal protective equipment.



VII.    While general operations and maintenance are being performed there are times the monitors will alert the presence of Chlorine inside the room. This activation occurs when:

a.    Fixed Chlorine monitors will activate at 0.5 ppm with a visual and audible alarm will be present and will continue alarming after 1.0 ppm.

b.    Portable Chlorine monitors will activate at 0.5 ppm and are carried on the employee while inside the room which will give a visual and audible alarm.  The Water Treatment Plant Chlorine

Scrubber will activate at 1.0 ppm.



Response to a Chlorine Leak



I.        At times when only one Operator is on duty he/she will don an SCBA and take the personal portable   

            Chlorine meter to the Chlorine Room doorway to determine if it is a false alarm or an actual leak.  After this  

            is performed he/she shall then proceed to the initial staging area.   NEVER MAKE ENTRY ALONE!

Disposal of Chlorine Remaining in Container



Stopping a Chlorine leak with the Chlorine Kit B is one interim measure to ensure that the leak is slowed down or stopped.  The one ton container must be emptied as soon as possible by either drawing off the gas or have the Chlorine supplier remove as soon as possible (within 24 hours) of leak.



The Chlorine will need to be drawn off if possible using the emergency draw-down valve on the Kit B.



First Aid for Chlorine Exposure



ALWAYS CALL 911 FOR SOMEONE THAT HAS EXPOSED TO CHLORINE!!



General



        A.    Be cautious, do not become a casualty yourself.

B.    Prompt treatment is essential.  Firmness and assurance to exposed persons will assist in alleviating anxiety.

C.    Immediately remove exposed person to an uncontaminated area.

D.    Remove any contaminated clothing and wash contaminated parts of the body.

        E.    Never give anything by mouth to an unconscious person.

        F.    Call a physician, obtain medical assistance.



Inhalation of Chlorine Gas



        A.    If breathing has ceased



            1.    Commence artificial respiration immediately.

2.    Administer oxygen as soon as possible.  The SCBA will be efficient enough on free-flow until the ambulance arrives.



        B.    If breathing has not ceased



            1.    Place patient into a comfortable position if possible.

2.    Administer oxygen as soon as possible or get the patient to 

            3.    Keep patient warm and at rest.

            4.    Render any other necessary first aid.



Contact of Liquid Chlorine in the Eye



A.    Flush eyes immediately with copious amounts of running water for 20 (twenty) minutes.

B.    Forcibly hold eyelids apart to ensure complete irrigation of all eye and lid tissues.

        C.    Do not attempt chemical neutralization of any kind.









Contact of Liquid Chlorine on the Skin



        A.    Emergency Shower, removing clothes in shower.

        B.    Wash well with copious amounts of soap and water.

        C.    Apply nothing to skin.



Protective Equipment and Clothing



I.    Normal operations require specific equipment and shall include:



a.    Respiratory protection shall be the highest priority.  The highest respiratory and eye protection shall only be achieved by using an SCBA with a full-face mask.

b.    Protection of the skin shall be achieved by using latex gloves, Tyvex suit or long sleeve shirt.

c.    A full-face mask and Chlorine cartridge can be used for connecting, disconnecting, loading/unloading of cylinders under normal conditions.



II.    Emergency operations shall require specific equipment and will include:

a.    An SCBA with a full-face mask shall be worn during any maintenance procedures or when a leak is present.

b.    Protection from Chlorine for the body shall be Level C or Tyvex Suit.

c.    Protective

clothing for over 25ppm responses shall be a Level A or Level B suit.

d.    Latex or Nitrile gloves shall be used always when working with Chlorine.



III.    Protection against gaseous Chlorine is especially important and will include:



a.    When gaseous Chlorine combines with water (including perspiration) it will form and produce Hypochlorous Acid.  When Chlorine gas dissolves in water or on the skin this acid creates mild skin burns and proper PPE shall be used.

b.    When gaseous Chlorine has been determined to be over 25ppm all employees shall use a Level A or Level B suit.



Emergency Response



Protective clothing for rescue, emergency repairs and maintenance shall be required.  Protective clothing for rescue employees, such as Level A, B or C suits will provide the necessary protection and shall be used to prevent exposure which can cause damage to your skin.



When an emergency occurs, the BGMU Haz Mat Technicians will donn special protective clothing that is available in the BGMU Hazardous Materials Trailer which is located at the Water Treatment Plant at 16 Chestnut Street.  Scott SCBA with full-face masks shall be used to ensure the highest respiratory protection for all employees.



Once a chlorine leak has occurred a decision will be made by the BGMU Safety Department to ensure that all personnel have the appropriate personal protective equipment and shall be used throughout the incident.

















PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT



I.    Personal Protective Equipment for a Chlorine response will be housed in the BGMU Hazardous Materials Trailer which is located at the Water Treatment Plant at 16 Chestnut Street and will be used in conjunction with equipment already stored at the facilities which includes:



a.    The Hazardous Materials Trailer has thirteen (13) Scott 60-minute Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA) ten (10) spare cylinders and each employee has a personal full-face piece mask.



b.    The Water Treatment Plant has four (4) Scott 45-

minute Self Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA), spare cylinders and each employee has a personal full-face piece masks.



c.    A Kit B Chlorine Emergency Repair Kit is immediately available at the Water Treatment Plant Chlorine storage area and another kit is carried in the BGMU Hazardous Materials Trailer.

        

d.    One Portable Chlorine Monitor is immediately available at the Water Treatment Plant and a spare monitor is located inside the BGMU Hazardous Materials Trailer.



e.    Boxes of Level A, B and C suits are stored in the BGMU Hazardous Materials Trailer for each BGMU Haz Mat Technician.



f.    Gloves, boots, personal clothing and other materials are immediately available in the BGMU Hazardous Materials Trailer.



SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS



When a chlorine leak occurs, each case must be handled on its own merits.  Decisions must be made which will minimize the amount of Chlorine that is released while at the same time ensuring our employees provide warning and proper rescue to other employees.



Normal work clothing will provide all the protection that is required for a short period of time it takes to escape from an emergency.  Such clothing, in combination with proper respiratory equipment can be satisfactory for very brief periods required for rescue or emergency valve closing.



Extended exposure to Chlorine will be handled by the BGMU Haz Mat Technicians with assistance from the Bowling Green Fire Department and/or Medical Center Ambulance Service when requested.  The BGFD and MED Center Ambulance Service will have specific duties which will be handled by the Incident Commander and included within the Joint Unified Command, Decon or Rescue services.



Judgment must be used when there are high concentrations of Chlorine gas or prolonged exposure is required.  There may be times when persons may not have the option of moving out of the Chlorine gas and other arrangements may be advised to those persons.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

                     

- Must be developed and implemented by all employers to handle emergencies



- Be in writing and available for inspection and copying by:



    1)    Employees or their representatives

    2)    OSHA personnel

    3)    Any regulatory agency or its representatives

    4)    Suppliers of potentially hazardous materials.



- Employers who evacuate the workplace in an emergency and do not allow any employee to respond are exempt from this requirement which is provided in the BGMU Emergency Response Plan in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.38 (a).



- ELEMENTS OF THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



   (A)    Pre-emergency planning (Refer to BGMU ERP).



   (B)    Personnel roles, lines of authority, training and communication (Refer to BGMU ERP).



   (C)    Emergency recognition and prevention (Refer to BGMU ERP).

(i)    The BGMU highest ranking employee on the scene shall become the individual in charge and be the site-specific Incident Commander.  All emergency personnel and their communications shall be coordinated and contr

olled through the individual in charge of the ICS, and be assisted by other senior agency officials.



(ii)    The individual in charge of ICS shall be in charge of the BGMU Hazardous Materials Team and all on-scene emergency responders.



(iii)    The ICS shall limit the number of emergency response personnel at the emergency site, in those areas of potential or actual exposure to incident or site hazards, to those who are actively performing emergency operations, with BGMU assisting in the Site Security.



(iv)    The Bowling Green Fire Department and Medical Center Ambulance Service will operate at the incident site per Standard Operating Procedures established by their agencies for responses.



(v)    The Medical Center Emergency Medical Services (EMS), as a minimum, shall also stand by with medical equipment and transportation capability.



(E)    SKILLED SUPPORT PERSONNEL: Personnel, not necessarily BGMU employees, who are skilled in the operation of certain equipment, such as mechanized earth moving or digging equipment or crane equipment are such listed.  These personnel who are needed temporarily to perform immediate emergency support work and who will be or may be exposed to the hazards at an emergency response scene, are not required to meet the training required in this paragraph.









However, these personnel shall be given an initial briefing at the site prior to their participation in any emergency response. The initial briefing shall include instruction in the wearing of appropriate personal protective equipment, what chemical hazards are involved, and what duties are to be performed.  All other appropriate safety and health precautions provided to BGMU employees shall be used to assure the safety and health of these personnel.



(F)    ADVISORY EMPLOYEES: Employees who, in the course of their regular job duties, work with and are trained in the hazards of specific hazardous substances will be called Specialists in their field.  They will be called upon to p

rovide technical advice or assistance at a hazardous substance release incident to the individual in charge and shall receive training and demonstrate competency in the area of their specialization annually.



(G)    FIRST RESPONDER AWARENESS LEVEL: First responders at the awareness level are individuals who are likely to witness or discover a hazardous substance release and who have been trained to initiate an emergency response sequence by notifying the proper authorities of the release.  They would take no further action beyond notifying the proper authorities of the release.  First responders at the awareness level shall have sufficient training to have had sufficient experience to objectively demonstrate competency in the following areas:



    (a)     Understanding of hazardous materials and associated risks

    (b)     Understand the potential outcome when hazardous materials are present

    (c)    Ability to identify hazardous materials

    (d)    Ability to recognize hazardous materials in an emergency

(e)    Understanding the First Responder Awareness Level's role in a hazardous material emergency

(f)    Understand site security and control and the Emergency Response Guidebook

(g)    Ability to recognize the need for additional resources and to make appropriate notifications



(H)      HAZARDOUS MATERIALS TECHNICIAN:  Hazardous Materials Technicians are individuals who respond to releases or potential releases for the purpose of stopping the release.  They assume a more aggressive role than the Operations Level in that they will approach the point of release in order to plug, patch or otherwise stop the release of a hazardous substance.  Hazardous Materials Technicians shall have received at least 72 hours of training including Awareness and Operations Level training.  They must have competency in the following areas and the employer shall certify them in:



    (a)    Recognition of health and safety hazards

    (b)    Methods to minimize risk from safety and health hazards

    (c)    Safe use of co

ntrol equipment

    (d)    Selection and use of appropriate PPE

    (e)    Safe operating procedures to be used at the incident scene

    (f)    Techniques of coordination with other employees to minimize risks

(g)    Appropriate response to overexposure from health hazards or injury to themselves and other employees

    (h)    Recognition of subsequent symptoms which may result from over-exposures

(vi)    LEVEL A - The highest level of respiratory and skin protection is necessary.



The following constitutes LEVEL A protection:  Refer to BGMU Hazardous Materials Team SOGs.



        LEVEL A - The highest respiratory and skin protection shall be used when:



(a)    Chlorine concentration is determined to be equal to or greater than the "IDLH" (OSHA limits 30 ppm) then Level A suits will be mandated for use while performing emergency repairs such as a fusible plug, broken or punctured cylinder, valve broken off with no scrubber or multiple cylinders.

(b)    PPE may be of a lower level after monitoring or determining there any listed above has not occurred.



(vii)    LEVEL B - The highest respiratory protection is necessary but a lesser level of skin protection is needed.



        The following constitutes LEVEL B protection: Refer to BGMU PPE SOG's.



LEVEL B protection should be used when:



(a)    Chlorine concentration is determined to be equal to or greater than the "IDLH" (OSHA limits 30 ppm) then Level B suits will be mandated for use while performing emergency repairs.

        (b)    The atmosphere contains less than 19.5 percent oxygen; or

(c)    The presence of

incompletely identified vapors or gases is indicated by a direct-reading organic vapor detection instrument, but vapors and gases are not suspected of containing high levels of chemicals harmful to skin or capable of being absorbed through the skin.



NOTE:  This involves atmospheres with "IDLH" concentrations of specific substances that present severe inhalation hazards and that do not represent a severe skin hazard; or that do not meet the criteria for use of air purifying respirators.











(viii)    LEVEL C - The concentration(s) and type(s) of airborne substance(s) is known and the criteria for using air-purifying respirators are met.

        LEVEL C protection should be used when:



(a)    The atmospheric contaminants, liquid splashes, or other direct contact will not adversely affect or be absorbed through any exposed skin and a Tyvex Suit is needed;

        (b)    All criteria for the use of air-purifying respirators are met.



(ix)    LEVEL D protection should be used when:



        (a)    The atmosphere contains no known hazard; and  

(b)    Work functions preclude splashes, immersion, or the potential for unexpected inhalation of or contact with hazardous levels of any chemicals.

PROCEDURE FOR HANDLING EMERGENCY RESPONSE:



The BGMU senior official at the scene will:



    (a)    Establish and become the individual in charge of a site-specific                 Incident Command System (ICS).



(b)    Shall be the individual in charge of ICS and shall identify hazardous substances and conditions present

and shall address site analysis, engineering controls, maximum exposure levels, hazardous substances handling procedures, and use of NEW technology.



(c)    Based on the hazardous substances or conditions present, the individual in charge of the ICS shall implement emergency operations, and assure that the PPE worn is appropriate.  Minimum protection shall be met.



(d)    Individual in charge of the ICS shall limit the number of personnel at the scene to those actively involved in performing the Hazardous Materials Response.



(e)    Back-up personnel shall stand by with rescue equipment.  Basic life support personnel shall stand by with medical equipment and transportation.



(f)    Individual in charge shall designate a Safety Officer who shall identify and evaluate hazards and provide direction with respect to the safety of operations.



(g)    If an IDLH or imminent danger condition exists, the Safety Officer shall have authority to alter, suspend, or terminate activities.



(h)    After emergency is terminated, individual in charge shall implement decontamination procedures.

HAZARDOUS MATERIALS (HAZMAT) TEAMS



The Bowling Green Fire Department Hazardous Materials Team will be notified if manpower, extra equipment or decontamination is required and there are an insufficient number of BGMU Hazardous Materials Personnel available.  This shall be accomplished by the BGMU Dispatcher contacting 911.



CONTRACTORS AND SUB-CONTRACTORS



An employer who retains contractors or subcontractor services for work in hazardous waste operations shall inform those contractors, sub-contractors, or their representative of the site emergency response procedures.  They shall at least include potential fire, explosion, health, safety and other hazards dealing with the hazardous waste operations that have been identified in the employer's information program.  No contractor or sub-contractor shall perform hot-work around any hazardous material with in the treatment plants.  The Chlorine B

uilding is a NO hot-work facility.



PROGRAM AVAILABILITY



The written safety and health program shall be made available to any contractor or subcontractor or their representative who will be involved with the hazardous waste operation.   This shall be given to employees and their designated representatives, OSHA personnel and to personnel of other Federal, State or local agencies with regulatory authority over the site.
